<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>While the athletes are undoubtedly impressive, the real star of the Olympics thus far is the remarkable setting of the freestyle skiing Big Air event. <div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
REAL ESTATE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/07/young-americans-overwhelmingly-say-it-s-a-bad-time-to-buy-a-house?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
Young Americans shun the housing market
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/07/young-americans-overwhelmingly-say-it-s-a-bad-time-to-buy-a-house?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="Bart Simpson writing, " I won't look at real estate until 2026"" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/58f8f60c96fcdaee351654867406654cfc2f4568-800x604.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>The Simpsons/20th TV Animation via <a href="http://ranzey.com/">Ranzey.com</a><br></em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">More than 80% of Americans ages 18–34 said now was a <a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/gen-z-millenials-bad-time-buy-house-real-estate-2022-2?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>bad </em>time</a> to buy a house, according to a Fannie Mae survey released yesterday. Their gloomy outlook is shared by the broader population: A record-low proportion of Americans—just 25%—said it was a good time to buy a house right now.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">It’s not a good time if you can’t afford it</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The median home-sale price reached a record high of $365,000 in January, according to Redfin. That’s a 16% jump from the previous January and a 28% increase from January 2019.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Skyrocketing home prices highlight the severe demand–supply imbalance that emerged in the housing market over the pandemic.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Interest in buying homes soared thanks to historically low interest rates and the desire to avoid your trumpet-playing neighbor at all costs.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>But the supply of available houses has not kept up—not even close. In fact, the 910,000 homes for sale at the end of December was the lowest since the National Association of Realtors began keeping track in 1999.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It all amounted to January being the most competitive month in US housing market history, Redfin said.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">But young people are getting squeezed harder than most</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Among the reasons why…</p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><strong style="color:#000">The disappearing starter home: </strong></span><span>The US’ supply of properties 1,400 square feet or smaller (the ones ideal for your first home) has </span><span><a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/housing-market-starter-home-shortage-boomers-downsizing-retirement-millennial-demand-2021-11?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">fallen</a></span><span> to its lowest level in 50 years. Starter homes accounted for just 7% of construction in 2019, compared to 40% in 1980.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><strong style="color:#000">Battle for the suburbs: </strong></span><span>Home prices are rising the fastest in suburbs with a higher share of children—neighborhoods where millennials are most interested in buying homes.</span>
</li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Millennials like to think they’re the main character in every story, but in this case…they actually are. Many of them are about to <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-02-04/follow-the-kids-to-see-where-u-s-housing-boom-still-has-legs?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">hit 32</a>, which is the median age of first-time home buyers in the US. Therefore, “As millennials go, so goes the housing market,” said Zillow economist Nicole Bachaud.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TRAVEL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/Frontier-Spirit-airlines-merge?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
New airline with zero legroom just dropped
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/Frontier-Spirit-airlines-merge?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="A photo illustration combing Spirit and Frontier Airlines jets." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/e7c41b2de2a438a010e5ac840e948606c376c852-1500x1000.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Photo Illustration: Dianna “Mick” McDougall; Sources: Spirit Airlines, Frontier Airlines</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Frontier Airlines and Spirit Airlines announced plans on Monday to <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/07/business/frontier-spirit-airlines-merger.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">merge</a> in a $6.6 billion dollar deal that, if approved, would create the fifth-largest US airline.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Spirit and Frontier say the deal would create a discount Megazord able to compete with the top four US airlines (American, Delta, United, and Southwest), which combined control about 80% of the domestic market. According to Spirit and Frontier, the deal would provide $1 billion in annual savings for consumers and create 10,000 new jobs by 2026. Also, imagine all the new ways they could tweet, “We’re sorry. DM us and we’ll try to get this settled.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The deal is expected to close in the second half of 2022, but before that can happen, it needs to get past regulators—and they’ve already signaled a distaste for airline alliances.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In September, the Justice Department sued to unwind a “de facto merger” between American Airlines and JetBlue.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In 2016, a more merger-friendly Justice Department allowed Alaska Air to buy Virgin for $2.6 billion, but required the company to scale back a partnership with American to do so.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Fun fact: </strong>A combined Frontier and Spirit Airlines would hold more than a quarter of the market at Orlando’s airport—more than any other airline.—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENTERTAINMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/matrix-coproducer-sues-warner-bros-hbo-max-release?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
‘The Matrix’ gets even more complicated
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/matrix-coproducer-sues-warner-bros-hbo-max-release?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="Matrix Resurrections movie poster" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/a93a7c75ce42c449fcee240e732953737513becc-534x343.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>The Matrix Resurrections/Warner Bros.</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Village Roadshow Entertainment, co-producers of <em>The Matrix Resurrections</em>, <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/26629861.0/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuaW5kaWV3aXJlLmNvbS8yMDIyLzAyL3ZpbGxhZ2Utcm9hZHNob3ctc3Vlcy1oYm8tbWF4LW1hdHJpeC1yZXN1cnJlY3Rpb25zLTEyMzQ2OTcwNTQvP3V0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1tYiZ1dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1tb3JuaW5nX2JyZXc/5f10d6a212c71038741b0759Bd2f61ac0?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sued</a> Warner Bros. yesterday for allegedly hatching a plan to pad HBO Max’s numbers by releasing the film simultaneously in theaters and on the streaming service.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">This story begins in the early days of the pandemic, </strong>when<strong style="color:#000"> </strong>Warner Bros. announced it would release its entire 2021 slate of theatrical films in cinemas <em>and</em> on its HBO Max streaming service on the same day. The strategy: meet customers where they were (on the couch).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This was effectively an admission that streaming subscribers are the real money-makers for movies, which peeved talent and producers whose deals are structured on box office revenue. And when it came to box office revenue, Neo didn’t bring the goods.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><em>The Matrix Resurrections </em></span><span>has grossed a measly $37 million in US theaters since its December 22 release date, flopping harder than the two previous Matrix entries.</span>
</li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In the lawsuit, Village Roadshow claims that Warner Bros. pushed up the release date (originally slated for 2022) to juice 2021 year-end HBO Max subscribers, knowingly self-sabotaging its box office performance. It also accused Warner Bros. of ignoring the <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/26629861.0/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubW9ybmluZ2JyZXcuY29tL2RhaWx5L3N0b3JpZXMvMjAyMS8wOC8yNy9zYW1lZGF5LXN0cmVhbWluZy1jYXVzZXMtbW92aWUtcGlyYWN5LXJhbXA_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPW1iJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09bmV3c2xldHRlciZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldyZtaWQ9N2ZhZTA1OWIwOTM5MmMwNzYwMDZhNDE4YWMzNmIxYjg/5f10d6a212c71038741b0759B56fd07e7?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wave of piracy</a> that’s hit streaming releases, further denting the flick’s earnings potential.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> This isn’t the first time a movie’s dual release has sparked legal drama. Last year, Scarlett Johansson sued Disney for $80 million after its simultaneous release of <em>Black Widow</em> on Disney+ and in theaters cost her a chunk of a box office-based bonus (the two sides later settled out of court).<em>—MM</em></p>
</div>

<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/IRS-facial-recognition-software?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
The IRS backs off of facial recognition tech
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/IRS-facial-recognition-software?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="A facial recognition demonstration at CES." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/40a1e69c3df7f199901dcf94fc4db68a7c199fd5-1024x683.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>DAVID MCNEW/AFP via Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The IRS doesn’t want to see your face anymore. After receiving backlash from privacy advocates and bipartisan lawmakers, the IRS is <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2022/02/07/tech/irs-facial-recognition-idme/index.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">abandoning</a> its use of third-party facial recognition software ID.me.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What happened? </strong>In November, the IRS announced that by summer 2022 all taxpayers would need to provide documents and a video selfie to the third-party company ID.me in order to use the agency’s website. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">ID.me was previously used in a limited capacity by the IRS, and it’s also utilized by 30 states for unemployment services. But as this year’s tax season kicked off on January 24, the agency’s use of facial recognition came under more scrutiny.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Critics pointed out a slew of issues with ID.me:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The process is challenging for taxpayers without a smartphone or web camera.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Facial recognition tech has been criticized for misidentifying people of color, gender-nonconforming people, and women.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>ID.me uses “one-to-many” matching—meaning it keeps a database of user images.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>ID.me’s terms of service grant the company the right to share data it collects with the police, government, and “select partners.”</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> The IRS says that its transition away from ID.me will take place in the coming weeks and won’t cause any problems for tax filers.—<em>MK</em></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>For more updates on facial recognition and other futuristic technologies, subscribe to <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=inline&utm_campaign=link&email={email}&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Emerging Tech Brew</a>.</em></p>
</div>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>Tech investor Peter Thiel wrote a $500,000 check to thefacebook.com in 2004; when Facebook IPO’d in 2012, he cashed out a chunk of his holdings for $638 million. <p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“Age is just a number.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Dutch speedskater Ireen Wüst became the first athlete in history to win an individual gold medal at <a href="https://www.npr.org/2022/02/07/1078826041/ireen-wust-gold-winter-olympics?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">five different Olympics</a> after her win in the 1,500 meters Monday. Now 35, she won her first gold at the Turin Olympics in 2006, when she was 19.<br><br><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>Matt Saincome is going to get rich or lose it all. <th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GAMES
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="#">
<font color="#000000">
The puzzle section
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Brew Mini: </strong>This week’s Minis are both themed around that big football matchup on Sunday. <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/07/brew-mini-big-game?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Get ready for the big game here</a>.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Oscar trivia</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This year’s Academy Award nominees will be released today. To mark the occasion, we’ll give you a famous quote from a Best Picture-winning movie and the year it was released. You have to name the movie.</p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“There has to be a mathematical explanation for how bad that tie is.” (2001)</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“I’ll wait for you at the train station every day at five.” (2008)</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“I do wish we could chat longer, but I’m having an old friend for dinner. Bye.” (1991)</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“This trial…the whole world…it’s all…show business.” (2002)</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“I am 42 years old; in less than a year I will be dead. Of course I don’t know that yet, and in a way, I am dead already.” (1999)</span></li>
</ol>
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>
</table>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nREAL ESTATE\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/07/young-americans-overwhelmingly-say-it-s-a-bad-time-to-buy-a-house?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nYoung Americans shun the housing market \n\u003c/font\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"text-decoration:none;border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/07/young-americans-overwhelmingly-say-it-s-a-bad-time-to-buy-a-house?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Bart Simpson writing, \"I won't look at real estate until 2026\"\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/58f8f60c96fcdaee351654867406654cfc2f4568-800x604.png?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe Simpsons/20th TV Animation via \u003ca href=\"http://ranzey.com/\"\u003eRanzey.com\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eMore than 80% of Americans ages 18–34 said now was a \u003ca href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/gen-z-millenials-bad-time-buy-house-real-estate-2022-2?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003ebad \u003c/em\u003etime\u003c/a\u003e to buy a house, according to a Fannie Mae survey released yesterday. Their gloomy outlook is shared by the broader population: A record-low proportion of Americans—just 25%—said it was a good time to buy a house right now.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIt’s not a good time if you can’t afford it\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe median home-sale price reached a record high of $365,000 in January, according to Redfin. That’s a 16% jump from the previous January and a 28% increase from January 2019.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSkyrocketing home prices highlight the severe demand–supply imbalance that emerged in the housing market over the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eInterest in buying homes soared thanks to historically low interest rates and the desire to avoid your trumpet-playing neighbor at all costs.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBut the supply of available houses has not kept up—not even close. In fact, the 910,000 homes for sale at the end of December was the lowest since the National Association of Realtors began keeping track in 1999.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt all amounted to January being the most competitive month in US housing market history, Redfin said.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBut young people are getting squeezed harder than most\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAmong the reasons why…\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe disappearing starter home: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe US’ supply of properties 1,400 square feet or smaller (the ones ideal for your first home) has \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/housing-market-starter-home-shortage-boomers-downsizing-retirement-millennial-demand-2021-11?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efallen\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e to its lowest level in 50 years. Starter homes accounted for just 7% of construction in 2019, compared to 40% in 1980.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBattle for the suburbs: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHome prices are rising the fastest in suburbs with a higher share of children—neighborhoods where millennials are most interested in buying homes.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eMillennials like to think they’re the main character in every story, but in this case…they actually are. Many of them are about to \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-02-04/follow-the-kids-to-see-where-u-s-housing-boom-still-has-legs?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehit 32\u003c/a\u003e, which is the median age of first-time home buyers in the US. Therefore, “As millennials go, so goes the housing market,” said Zillow economist Nicole Bachaud.—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFrontier Airlines and Spirit Airlines announced plans on Monday to \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/07/business/frontier-spirit-airlines-merger.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emerge\u003c/a\u003e in a $6.6 billion dollar deal that, if approved, would create the fifth-largest US airline.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSpirit and Frontier say the deal would create a discount Megazord able to compete with the top four US airlines (American, Delta, United, and Southwest), which combined control about 80% of the domestic market. According to Spirit and Frontier, the deal would provide $1 billion in annual savings for consumers and create 10,000 new jobs by 2026. Also, imagine all the new ways they could tweet, “We’re sorry. DM us and we’ll try to get this settled.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe deal is expected to close in the second half of 2022, but before that can happen, it needs to get past regulators—and they’ve already signaled a distaste for airline alliances.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn September, the Justice Department sued to unwind a “de facto merger” between American Airlines and JetBlue.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn 2016, a more merger-friendly Justice Department allowed Alaska Air to buy Virgin for $2.6 billion, but required the company to scale back a partnership with American to do so.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eFun fact: \u003c/strong\u003eA combined Frontier and Spirit Airlines would hold more than a quarter of the market at Orlando’s airport—more than any other airline.—\u003cem\u003eMK\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/a93a7c75ce42c449fcee240e732953737513becc-534x343.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe Matrix Resurrections/Warner Bros.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eVillage Roadshow Entertainment, co-producers of \u003cem\u003eThe Matrix Resurrections\u003c/em\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/26629861.0/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuaW5kaWV3aXJlLmNvbS8yMDIyLzAyL3ZpbGxhZ2Utcm9hZHNob3ctc3Vlcy1oYm8tbWF4LW1hdHJpeC1yZXN1cnJlY3Rpb25zLTEyMzQ2OTcwNTQvP3V0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1tYiZ1dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1tb3JuaW5nX2JyZXc/5f10d6a212c71038741b0759Bd2f61ac0?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esued\u003c/a\u003e Warner Bros. yesterday for allegedly hatching a plan to pad HBO Max’s numbers by releasing the film simultaneously in theaters and on the streaming service.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThis story begins in the early days of the pandemic, \u003c/strong\u003ewhen\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e \u003c/strong\u003eWarner Bros. announced it would release its entire 2021 slate of theatrical films in cinemas \u003cem\u003eand\u003c/em\u003e on its HBO Max streaming service on the same day. The strategy: meet customers where they were (on the couch).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis was effectively an admission that streaming subscribers are the real money-makers for movies, which peeved talent and producers whose deals are structured on box office revenue. And when it came to box office revenue, Neo didn’t bring the goods.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe Matrix Resurrections \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003ehas grossed a measly $37 million in US theaters since its December 22 release date, flopping harder than the two previous Matrix entries.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn the lawsuit, Village Roadshow claims that Warner Bros. pushed up the release date (originally slated for 2022) to juice 2021 year-end HBO Max subscribers, knowingly self-sabotaging its box office performance. It also accused Warner Bros. of ignoring the \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/26629861.0/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubW9ybmluZ2JyZXcuY29tL2RhaWx5L3N0b3JpZXMvMjAyMS8wOC8yNy9zYW1lZGF5LXN0cmVhbWluZy1jYXVzZXMtbW92aWUtcGlyYWN5LXJhbXA_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPW1iJnV0bV9tZWRpdW09bmV3c2xldHRlciZ1dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldyZtaWQ9N2ZhZTA1OWIwOTM5MmMwNzYwMDZhNDE4YWMzNmIxYjg/5f10d6a212c71038741b0759B56fd07e7?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewave of piracy\u003c/a\u003e that’s hit streaming releases, further denting the flick’s earnings potential.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e This isn’t the first time a movie’s dual release has sparked legal drama. Last year, Scarlett Johansson sued Disney for $80 million after its simultaneous release of \u003cem\u003eBlack Widow\u003c/em\u003e on Disney+ and in theaters cost her a chunk of a box office-based bonus (the two sides later settled out of court).\u003cem\u003e—MM\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nThe IRS backs off of facial recognition tech\n\u003c/font\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eDAVID MCNEW/AFP via Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe IRS doesn’t want to see your face anymore. After receiving backlash from privacy advocates and bipartisan lawmakers, the IRS is \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2022/02/07/tech/irs-facial-recognition-idme/index.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eabandoning\u003c/a\u003e its use of third-party facial recognition software ID.me.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat happened? \u003c/strong\u003eIn November, the IRS announced that by summer 2022 all taxpayers would need to provide documents and a video selfie to the third-party company ID.me in order to use the agency’s website. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eID.me was previously used in a limited capacity by the IRS, and it’s also utilized by 30 states for unemployment services. But as this year’s tax season kicked off on January 24, the agency’s use of facial recognition came under more scrutiny.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCritics pointed out a slew of issues with ID.me:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe process is challenging for taxpayers without a smartphone or web camera.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFacial recognition tech has been criticized for misidentifying people of color, gender-nonconforming people, and women.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eID.me uses “one-to-many” matching—meaning it keeps a database of user images.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eID.me’s terms of service grant the company the right to share data it collects with the police, government, and “select partners.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e The IRS says that its transition away from ID.me will take place in the coming weeks and won’t cause any problems for tax filers.—\u003cem\u003eMK\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eFor more updates on facial recognition and other futuristic technologies, subscribe to \u003ca
